newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuelans protest ICA toll road hike.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelans protest ICA toll road hike.

text.p: Shops, factories and transport companies closed down in the Venezuelan port town La Guaira Wednesday as residents stepped up protests over a sharp increase in tolls on the highway to the capital.

"Ninety percent of businesses are closed and public transport, which is the most important, is paralyzed," said Lenin Marcano, mayor of the La Vargas district through which most of the toll road runs.
Marcano has led protests against the recent toll increase by the highway concession owner Asoven, which is majority owned by Mexican construction giant Empresas ICA.

He said the La Guaira port, Venezuela's largest, was only working for emergency cases at about five percent of normal capacity. The country's main international and national airports, also located in La Guaira, were operating normally.
The protest started at midnight Tuesday (0400 GMT Wednesday) and was due to continue until 6 p.m. local time (2200 GMT).

Since taking over the 10-mile (16-km) Caracas-La Guaira road in April Asoven has raised the round trip toll for private cars tenfold to 100 bolivars ($0.21) and set tolls for heavy goods traffic of over 10,000 bolivars ($20.80).
The increased tolls are to fund a $214 million investment program to improve and maintain the highway.
Transport and Communications Minister Moises Orozco Graterol has said the government will not be swayed by the protests since it cannot afford to fund the necessary repairs to the highway.
The 30-year concession is the first to be awarded under a reformed law passed in 1994.
